-pam

On Nov 19, 2008, at 8:10 PM, Pamela Sorooshian wrote:

> We played KUDUUK today at park day

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Re: Christmas Gift Suggestions
messages.msgSnippet: We played KUDUUK today at park day - it is a great game, really fun. Simple - lots of interaction,  strategic thinking enough for the more serious game
messages.messageBody:
We played KUDUUK today at park day - it is a great game, really fun.
Simple - lots of interaction, strategic thinking enough for the more
serious game players, but not burdensome to those who are not so
serious.

I got it hanging in the toys section of the 99 cent store.

However, there are two versions - the original version sold at
Starbucks and is more sophisticated. The version I got was sold
elsewhere and the rules are simplified (the game was bought by Mattel
and they simplified it).

I've played both and both are fun. I like the more complicated version
better - but the simplified version is still really good and has the
advantage of being quicker to learn so it works well for family get-
togethers and other spur-of-the-moment game playing.

-pam

On Nov 19, 2008, at 7:57 PM, Jay Ford wrote:

> We do have lots of games that are not the standard ones (Set, Apples
> to Apples, Taboo, Rush Hour) and more that I can't think of, but
> yes, games like those is what I was going for. Lots of links and

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Christmas Gift Suggestions
messages.msgSnippet: -=-  One of the best things to do would be to shop at a local game store instead of a toy store, if your area has them. (we have Uncles Games and some
messages.messageBody:
-=- One of the best things to do would be to shop at a local game
store instead of a toy store, if your area has them. (we have Uncles
Games and some independently owned stores around here that are great
for carrying top game titles that toy stores usually don't have)-=-

OH YES. Definitely.
When I was writing, I was picturing someone going into Active
Imagination (in Albuquerque) and asking for board game advice, but
the pictures in my head didn't seem to translate into e-mail. <bwg>

The games at toy stores tend to be more mainstream, less artsy.
Buying online is also a possibility.

We've done well with thrift store games. Once you know what you're
looking for, you might not have to buy it new.

Labyrinth got a lot of play here when it was new to the house.

Encore has been played a LOT, and I probably didn't think of that
because I've been playing it online (not as fun in writing as
singing, but still fun!).
http://sandradodd.com/music (halfway down that page)
http://lyricsgame.blogspot.com

Sandra

messages.subject: RE: [AlwaysLearning] Christmas Gift Suggestions
messages.msgSnippet: I haven t read all the replies, but one thing that came to mind that we ve enjoyed a lot over the years is Rush Hour Traffic Jam by Thinkfun.  Although it s a
messages.messageBody:
I haven't read all the replies, but one thing that came to mind that we've
enjoyed a lot over the years is Rush Hour Traffic Jam by Thinkfun. Although
it's a one person game, we always take turns and enjoy challenging each
other. We love a lot of the games by Thinkfun.



I also love Amazing Labyrinth and Master Labyrinth by the puzzle making
company Ravensburger. Makes my brain hurt sometimes. =)



Angela

> We have the usual games (checkers, chess, cards) and many common board
> games (Life, Scrabble, Monopoly etc), but are looking for something
> cool, new, and different.

> other
> suggestions that you have had fun with in your families.
>

Some of our faves:

Fluxx, Apples to Apples, Wise and Otherwise, Bananagrams, Set, Rumis,
Blokus, Settlers of Catan, Hive, Betrayal at House on the Hill, Five

~Jill

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Christmas Gift Suggestions
messages.msgSnippet: I really like this website for games:  http://www.funagain.com/control/main One thing I love is that they break things up into categories (two player,
messages.messageBody:
I really like this website for games: http://www.funagain.com/control/main

One thing I love is that they break things up into categories (two
player, strategy, family games, etc.) and have recommendations in each
area. There are also awards in those areas every year and they have
the award information. They are a wonderful resource.

Reading your list of games, there is a big area of games that you
haven't explored yet and that site is a good place to start. Lots of
very cool German games that are very different from games like
Monopoly and Life.

Some that I have enjoyed in the last few years:

San Juan (2+ player version of Puerto Rico which is 3+ and is supposed
to be even better - but San Juan is GREAT)
Blink (quick little card game)
The aMAZEing Labyrinth (loved it as a kid and it is still fun now)
Bohnanza
Settlers of Catan
Queen's necklace


Margaret

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Christmas Gift Suggestions
messages.msgSnippet: Our favorite game overall ever has been Five Crowns.  It s a card game from the company that made Set.  You can google it.    We re on our third deck.
messages.messageBody:
Our favorite game overall ever has been Five Crowns. It's a card
game from the company that made Set. You can google it. We're on
our third deck.

Personally, I don't like Life, Scrabble or Monopoly at all. But I
did see a Beatles Monopoly game at Macy's yesterday, and instead of
streets, there were albums. That might be fun for Christmas!

Ravensburger is a company that makes some very good games.

If you have kids who like mysteries and puzzles and deductive
reasoning, consider Clue or Scotland Yard.

Sandra

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Christmas Gift Suggestions
messages.msgSnippet: ... games (Life, Scrabble, Monopoly etc), but are looking for something cool, new, and different. Some of our favorites: Party games best played with 4+
messages.messageBody:
>> We have the usual games (checkers, chess, cards) and many common board
games (Life, Scrabble, Monopoly etc), but are looking for something
cool, new, and different.

Some of our favorites:

Party games best played with 4+ people:  Quelf (hilarious!!!), Apples to Apples (or Apples to Apples Jr), Cranium (mix of trivia, pictionary, charades, and other party games)

Strategy:  Settlers of Catan.   The regular board game requires 3-4 people to play.  If you want 5-6 people to play, you need to get the regular game + an expansion set.  There are also expansion sets for the game itself to add to the gameplay.  We love getting together with friends to play this game.  When my husband Ryan and I are at home, we play the Settlers of Catan card game which is for 2 players.  I like the card game better than the board game, honestly.

Cards:  Zombie Fluxx.   Ryan and I play this frequently.  It's called Fluxx because the rules and goal of the game change while you're playing.  The zombies add extra fun in the form of anti-goals.  A similar deck is Monty Python Fluxx, if your kids prefer Monty Python to Zombies. :)

I'm sure I'm forgetting something.  These days we play Catan and Fluxx mostly...  (except with our kids, but we're still in Candyland there.)

Definitely check out BoardGameGeek.com.  It's a terrific site, although you can end up sinking a lot of time into it if you like games. :)  Games magazine also just published their "Games 100", which has some interesting looking titles.  One of the best things to do would be to shop at a local game store instead of a toy store, if your area has them. (we have Uncles Games and some independently owned stores around here that are great for carrying top game titles that toy stores usually don't have)

-Renee

messages.subject: Christmas Gift Suggestions
messages.msgSnippet: I m looking for suggestions for games, puzzles, books, and other off- the-beaten path things to do to give as Christmas gifts and to also stash in the RV for
messages.messageBody:
I'm looking for suggestions for games, puzzles, books, and other off-
the-beaten path things to do to give as Christmas gifts and to also
stash in the RV for when we take road trips.

We have the usual games (checkers, chess, cards) and many common board
games (Life, Scrabble, Monopoly etc), but are looking for something
cool, new, and different.

I found a few things on the Mental Floss site, but am looking for other
suggestions that you have had fun with in your families.

My kids are 14 & 10.

Thanks!

Jay
